content:
illroute66 said
Could be this? https://downdetector.com/status/yahoo-mail/

It could be.

illroute66 said
Server works if I login to Yahoo Mail as I'm able to do that. Issue with Thunderbird login. Any ideas?

sing web mail uses none of the yahoo IMAP or SMTP servers, so you are not compering apples with apples.

However if the delay is measured in minutes it may be a timeout is happening where the server is simply not responding, or you have software (antivirus usually) that is blocking the connection and seeing abnormal activity. Firs up a cold restart of your computer and any modems or routers is a good idea.

content:
There is no supported method to revert to a previous version. Going backwards almost always looses data as the profile file formats change on update and are not downgraded.

Let me guess, it also asked you to set up your mail account again when first run by asking you for your email address and password. So it has probably decided to use a new profile. https://thunderbirdtweaks.blogspot.com/2019/09/i-lost-my-profilemail-on-update-to.html

To be honest however I have no idea what you would be doing to add shortcuts to your desktop for email, and I fail to understand about the specific folder either, unless you previously had filters in your profile and the new one does not have them.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Are you using authentication method of oauth in Thunderbird to connect to yahoo? (check account settings > server settings) You probably need to be.

creator: clistforseattle

content:
Thunderbird cannot move messages by changing folder location. So, unless you MOVED the messages, the messages are still available, my guess is they are where the default profile is. click help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder' in left column and click 'open folder'. you are now in the profile. Imap messages would be in the Imapmail folder and POP mail would be in the Mail folder and mail stored to Local Folders would be in Mail\Local Folders.

If you want an account on drive D, a simple way is to exit thunderbird, then COPY the account from the profile to drive D, restart thunderbird, and click the 'server settings' pane and change the 'Local Directory' pointer to point to the new location on D. Thunderbird will probably restart and it will use drive D. at this time, the account data in the mail profile may be deleted.
creator: davidsk
